3️⃣ Traction: Central banks will maintain low-for-long interest rates through this period of strong growth and these stances should become more effective as their reflationary credibility builds.
2️⃣ More fiscal support: Additional fiscal stimulus is being provided across the advanced economies, with packages worth close to $2 trillion expected to boost 📈 US growth this year.

1️⃣ Virus containment: COVID-19 second wave restrictions have been targeted successfully to curb the spread while limiting economic disruptions. Business 💼 spending growth has been resilient, and consumer 🛍 spending is poised to rebound as restrictions are relaxed this spring.

🔟 M&A may be the great equalizer.                          

Despite a volatile year that saw all-time high VIX levels, M&A activity 🤝 was comparable to other non-recessionary years during the past two decades.

9️⃣ Delivering growth has become more difficult, but investor interest has expanded.

Despite limited opportunities, investor interest in market growth 📈 has increased - this has caused the relative value of growth in the market to rise 160% higher than the past 20 years.

8️⃣ Retail investors are driving momentum in high-growth firms.

The stereotype of the retail investor as the passive income-oriented retiree was challenged in 2020. Retail investor 👩‍💻👨‍💻 ownership in high-growth companies increased by nearly 30%.

7️⃣ Energy transition and ESG interest are accelerating.

ESG 🌱 bonds proved resilient in 2020, with market issuance increasing by 62%— the largest dollar increase to date.

6️⃣ Equity markets show resilience.

Despite the pandemic, equity market performance remained strong, resulting in an expected increase of issuance in 2021.
Since last March, the rating agencies have issues 6x more downgrades than upgrades, with 91% in the high yield space. Consequently, the rating agencies are now more aligned for the year ahead 🗓.

5️⃣ Rating agencies took action.

Throughout 2020, several rating actions took place to reflect market dynamics 📈📉.

4️⃣ Debt markets have rebounded at record pace.

Central bank policies have aided in the rapid recovery of debt markets resulting in high levels of Investment Grade and High Yield debt issuances.

3️⃣ Mixed recovery timelines are expected for US firms, but strong cash positions lower uncertainty.

In ‘21 nearly two-thirds of S&P 500 firms will recover to ‘19 EPS levels.  Smaller firms face a slower recovery, but firms of all sizes have strengthened cash 💵 on balance sheet.

2️⃣ Unemployment trends vary, but a new business boom has emerged.

A record of +1 million entrepreneurs were inspired to seek out new business 💼 applications in 2020, signaling a potential new wave of innovation.

1️⃣ The COVID-19 recovery won’t be a global synchronization, unlike the downturn.

Over 90% of the world’s 🌎 economies went into recession during 2020, but the recovery is expected to be uneven with countries and US states trending differently.

While 2020 left us with uncertainty and an uneven recovery, 2021 may be the year for action.

J.P. Morgan’s Corporate Finance Advisory outlines 10 key trends that will help drive companies’ decision-making.

5⃣ While some industries saw an increase in sales, others saw a dramatic decrease 📉.

Cosmetics and sun care saw double-digit declines. Due to the rise in #WFH, individuals are wearing less or no make up. Sun care has also taken a hit due to travel restrictions around the world.

4⃣ ANSWER: Lockdowns & the shift to essential products caused an increase in sales of coffee 📈.

💊 Vitamins and supplements,
☕️ at home coffee products, 
💁‍♀️ and hair color products 

all saw drastic influxes in sales. Unsurprisingly, household cleaners & soap also saw a spike.

3️⃣ What products did consumers buy the most during COVID-19 lockdowns? 

Have a guess.

2⃣ #Ecommerce around the world, across sectors, has surged 💳.
 
As restrictions to leave the house lingered for months on end, consumers turned to online shopping. Ecommerce now accounts for 16.1% of all U.S. sales, up from 11.8% in Q1.

1⃣ Much of the world was forced into full or partial lockdowns since December 2019.
 
Given the uncertainty of the situation, #panicbuying took hold. Retailers were compelled to limit purchases of high-demand items, such as hand sanitizer and toilet paper 🧻.

After months of lockdown and social distancing as a result of COVID–19, consumers are shopping differently.

5️⃣Europe’s capitals are working to position as the next Silicon Valley. 🌉 
 
While the market faces some unique challenges, such as multiple languages and payment methods, there has been growth in VC funding across the continent.

4️⃣ Disruptions from the pandemic have been a catalyst for cybersecurity and regtech. 🔐
 
As entire industries transition to #WFH, it’s become critical for companies to adopt robust cybersecurity that maintains client satisfaction and meets regulatory requirements.

3️⃣ European companies are building payments from the ground up. 💳
 
Next-gen #payment companies are building their platforms from the ground up, so they can accept any form of payment and offer in-depth analytics for clients.

2️⃣Technology is transforming other industries.📱
 
While tech is seen as an enabler to a wide array of sectors, it has significantly impacted industries such as:

🩺  healthcare
🥡food delivery
💻streaming
🛍️e-commerce 

due to their recent shift to digital.

1️⃣ Opportunities are growing. 📈
 
Europe has seen an increasing number of tech companies grow to high-value IPOs and flourish in the aftermarket. The success has attracted additional capital to the market and is fueling rapid growth of the next wave of tech stars.

Despite volatile markets, #technology continues to accelerate 📈 in Europe. 

By how much has the tech industry outperformed the broader market in 2020? Read through the below THREAD on emerging tech trends in Europe for the answer 👇

For more insights 💡 from the J.P. Morgan Global Research Mid-Year Outlook and relevant disclosures, visit here: https://t.co/OjuiIebXxh

6⃣ Emerging Markets equities could still surprise on the upside. There are a number of supportive factors over the medium term, including China's V-shaped recovery. 

The relative GDP growth gap of EM to DM will be 3.3% in 2021 compared to only 1.6% in 2019 and 3.1% this year.
5⃣ USD has peaked, but is not due for a major downtrend. GBP is most vulnerable over the near term, and upward pressure will persist for CHF and JPY.
4⃣ We’ve seen record U.S. fixed income supply in 2020, but demand should push spreads tighter in the 2H 2020.
3⃣ S&P 500 still has 10% upside from current levels by early 2021, while technicals remain supportive with hedge fund and CTA positioning at only the ~25th to 30th percentile.
2⃣ Markets 📈📉 remain supported by central bank actions and fiscal support.

1⃣ Global growth is experiencing a consumer-led midyear bounce after the plunging by 16% in 1H, but the resurgence in the virus points to an incomplete recovery and a loss of output, profits and employment that won’t be fully recouped in 2020 and 2021.
